                            <term_definitions code="at0000">
                              <items id="text">Interpreter details UK</items>
                              <items id="description">Details about an individual's identified needs to have an interpreter involved in communication.</items>
                            </term_definitions>
                            <term_definitions code="at0001">
                              <items id="text">Type of interpretation</items>
                              <items id="description">Identification of the type of interpretation needed.</items>
                            </term_definitions>
                            <term_definitions code="at0003">
                              <items id="text">Comment</items>
                              <items id="description">Additional narrative description about the interpreter or the interpretation.</items>
                              <items id="comment">For example, the interaction with the interpreter was unsatisfactory and the individual may not have understood the content of the discussion with a clinician.</items>
                            </term_definitions>
                            <term_definitions code="at0004">
                              <items id="text">Interpreter</items>
                              <items id="description">Identification of the interpreter that either performed or is requested for the interpretation, including qualifications.</items>
                            </term_definitions>
                            <term_definitions code="at0005">
                              <items id="text">Sign language</items>
                              <items id="description">Sign language interpreter.</items>
                            </term_definitions>
                            <term_definitions code="at0006">
                              <items id="text">Spoken language</items>
                              <items id="description">Spoken language interpreter.</items>
                            </term_definitions>
                            <term_definitions code="at0009">
                              <items id="text">Modality</items>
                              <items id="description">The preferred way of interpretation or the way the interpretation was carried out.</items>
                            </term_definitions>
                            <term_definitions code="at0010">
                              <items id="text">On-site</items>
                              <items id="description">Physical attendence of the interpreter.</items>
                            </term_definitions>
                            <term_definitions code="at0011">
                              <items id="text">Video</items>
                              <items id="description">Video interpretation.</items>
                            </term_definitions>
                            <term_definitions code="at0012">
                              <items id="text">Telephone</items>
                              <items id="description">Telephone interpretation.</items>
                            </term_definitions>
                            <term_definitions code="at0013">
                              <items id="text">No preferences</items>
                              <items id="description">The individual has no preferences for the modality of the interpretation.</items>
                            </term_definitions>
                            <term_definitions code="at0025">
                              <items id="text">Tactile signing</items>
                              <items id="description">Tactile signing interpreter.</items>
                            </term_definitions>
                            <term_definitions code="at0027">
                              <items id="text">Gender</items>
                              <items id="description">The individual's preferred gender of the interpreter or the gender of the interpreter that was involved in the interpretation.</items>
                            </term_definitions>
                            <term_definitions code="at0028">
                              <items id="text">Male</items>
                              <items id="description">The individual preferres a male interpretor or the interpretation was performed by a male interpretor.</items>
                            </term_definitions>
                            <term_definitions code="at0029">
                              <items id="text">Female</items>
                              <items id="description">The individual preferres a female interpretor or the interpretation was performed by a female interpretor.</items>
                            </term_definitions>
                            <term_definitions code="at0031">
                              <items id="text">Primary language</items>
                              <items id="description">The individual's primary language, dialect and abilities to communicate in the specified language or dialect. Used for specifying preferences for interpretation or the way interpretation was carried out.</items>
                            </term_definitions>
                            <term_definitions code="at0032">
                              <items id="text">Additional language</items>
                              <items id="description">The individual's additional languages, dialects and abilities to communicate in the specified language or dialect. Used for specifying preferences for interpretation or the way interpretation was carried out.</items>
                            </term_definitions>
                            <term_definitions code="at0033">
                              <items id="text">Interpreter required</items>
                              <items id="description">Statement whether interpreter is required.</items>
                            </term_definitions>

                      <items id="description">@ internal @</items>

                    <term_definitions code="at0002">
                      <items id="text">Narrative summary</items>
                      <items id="description">This field is intended to capture relevant summary information about diagnoses, reasons for preferences and recommendations in a narrative format. It is envisaged that some of this information can be derived from more structured data, but this field allows the capture of a shared understanding between patient and clinician of the most important diagnoses and social factors, and it should act as a quick overview or snapshot which could be used for example in an emergency situation to gain a quick understanding of the most relevant information for this patient.</items>
                    </term_definitions>

                    <term_definitions code="at0005">

                      <items id="description">Details of other communication needs such as communication aids.</items>
                    </term_definitions>

                    <archetype_id>
                      <value>openEHR-EHR-EVALUATION.problem_diagnosis.v1</value>
                    </archetype_id>
                    <term_definitions code="at0000">
                      <items id="text">Problem/Diagnosis</items>
                      <items id="description">Details about a single identified health condition, injury, disability or any other issue which impacts on the physical, mental and/or social well-being of an individual.</items>
                      <items id="comment">Clear delineation between the scope of a problem versus a diagnosis is not easy to achieve in practice. For the purposes of clinical documentation with this archetype, problem and diagnosis are regarded as a continuum, with increasing levels of detail and supportive evidence usually providing weight towards the label of 'diagnosis'.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0001">
                      <items id="text">structure</items>
                      <items id="description">@ internal @</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0002">
                      <items id="text">Problem/Diagnosis name</items>
                      <items id="description">Identification of the problem or diagnosis, by name.</items>
                      <items id="comment">Coding of the name of the problem or diagnosis with a terminology is preferred, where possible.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0003">
                      <items id="text">Date/time clinically recognised</items>
                      <items id="description">Estimated or actual date/time the diagnosis or problem was recognised by a healthcare professional.</items>
                      <items id="comment">Partial dates are acceptable. If the subject of care is under the age of one year, then the complete date or a minimum of the month and year is necessary to enable accurate age calculations - for example, if used to drive decision support. Data captured/imported as "Age at time of clinical recognition" should be converted to a date using the subject's date of birth.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0005">
                      <items id="text">Severity</items>
                      <items id="description">An assessment of the overall severity of the problem or diagnosis.</items>
                      <items id="comment">If severity is included in the Problem/diagnosis name via precoordinated codes, this data element becomes redundant. Note: more specific grading of severity can be recorded using the Specific details SLOT.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0009">
                      <items id="text">Clinical description</items>
                      <items id="description">Narrative description about the problem or diagnosis.</items>
                      <items id="comment">Use to provide background and context, including evolution, episodes or exacerbations, progress and any other relevant details, about the problem or diagnosis.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0012">
                      <items id="text">Body site</items>
                      <items id="description">Identification of a simple body site for the location of the problem or diagnosis.</items>
                      <items id="comment">Coding of the name of the anatomical location with a terminology is preferred, where possible.
Use this data element to record precoordinated anatomical locations. If the requirements for recording the anatomical location are determined at run-time by the application or require more complex modelling such as relative locations then use the CLUSTER.anatomical_location or CLUSTER.relative_location within the 'Structured anatomical location' SLOT in this archetype. Occurrences for this data element are unbounded to allow for clinical scenarios such as describing a rash in multiple locations but where all of the other attributes are identical. If the anatomical location is included in the Problem/diagnosis name via precoordinated codes, this data element becomes redundant.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0030">
                      <items id="text">Date/time of resolution</items>
                      <items id="description">Estimated or actual date/time of resolution or remission for this problem or diagnosis, as determined by a healthcare professional.</items>
                      <items id="comment">Partial dates are acceptable. If the subject of care is under the age of one year, then the complete date or a minimum of the month and year is necessary to enable accurate age calculations - for example, if used to drive decision support. Data captured/imported as "Age at time of resolution" should be converted to a date using the subject's date of birth.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0032">
                      <items id="text">Tree</items>
                      <items id="description">@ internal @</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0039">
                      <items id="text">Structured body site</items>
                      <items id="description">A structured anatomical location for the problem or diagnosis.</items>
                      <items id="comment">Use this SLOT to insert the CLUSTER.anatomical_location or CLUSTER.relative_location archetypes if the requirements for recording the anatomical location are determined at run-time by the application or require more complex modelling such as relative locations.

If the anatomical location is included in the Problem/diagnosis name via precoordinated codes, use of this SLOT becomes redundant.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0043">
                      <items id="text">Specific details</items>
                      <items id="description">Details that are additionally required to record as unique attributes of this problem or diagnosis.</items>
                      <items id="comment">May include structured detail about the grading or staging of the diagnosis; diagnostic criteria, classification criteria or formal severity assessments such as Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0046">
                      <items id="text">Status</items>
                      <items id="description">Structured details for location-, domain-, episode- or workflow-specific aspects of the diagnostic process.</items>
                      <items id="comment">Use status or context qualifiers with care, as they are variably used in practice and interoperability cannot be assured unless usage is clearly defined with the community of use. For example: active status - active, inactive, resolved, in remission; evolution status - initial, interim/working, final; temporal status - current, past; episodicity status - first, new, ongoing; admission status - admission, discharge; or priority status - primary, secondary.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0047">
                      <items id="text">Mild</items>
                      <items id="description">The problem or diagnosis does not interfere with normal activity or may cause damage to health if left untreated.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0048">
                      <items id="text">Moderate</items>
                      <items id="description">The problem or diagnosis causes interference with normal activity or will damage health if left untreated.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0049">
                      <items id="text">Severe</items>
                      <items id="description">The problem or diagnosis prevents normal activity or will seriously damage health if left untreated.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0069">
                      <items id="text">Comment</items>
                      <items id="description">Additional narrative about the problem or diagnosis not captured in other fields.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0070">
                      <items id="text">Last updated</items>
                      <items id="description">The date this problem or diagnosis was last updated.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0071">
                      <items id="text">Extension</items>
                      <items id="description">Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.</items>
                      <items id="comment">For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0072">
                      <items id="text">Course description</items>
                      <items id="description">Narrative description about the course of the problem or diagnosis since onset.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0073">
                      <items id="text">Diagnostic certainty</items>
                      <items id="description">The level of confidence in the identification of the diagnosis.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0074">
                      <items id="text">Suspected</items>
                      <items id="description">The diagnosis has been identified with a low level of certainty.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0075">
                      <items id="text">Probable</items>
                      <items id="description">The diagnosis has been identified with a high level of certainty.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0076">
                      <items id="text">Confirmed</items>
                      <items id="description">The diagnosis has been confirmed against recognised criteria.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0077">
                      <items id="text">Date/time of onset</items>
                      <items id="description">Estimated or actual date/time that signs or symptoms of the problem/diagnosis were first observed.</items>
                      <items id="comment">Data captured/imported as "Age at onset" should be converted to a date using the subject's date of birth.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                  </children>

                    <is_unique>false</is_unique>

                      <lower_unbounded>false</lower_unbounded>
                      <upper_unbounded>true</upper_unbounded>
                      <lower>0</lower>
                    </interval>
                  </cardinality>

                    <archetype_id>
                      <value>openEHR-EHR-EVALUATION.problem_diagnosis.v1</value>
                    </archetype_id>
                    <term_definitions code="at0000">
                      <items id="text">Problem/Diagnosis</items>
                      <items id="description">Details about a single identified health condition, injury, disability or any other issue which impacts on the physical, mental and/or social well-being of an individual.</items>
                      <items id="comment">Clear delineation between the scope of a problem versus a diagnosis is not easy to achieve in practice. For the purposes of clinical documentation with this archetype, problem and diagnosis are regarded as a continuum, with increasing levels of detail and supportive evidence usually providing weight towards the label of 'diagnosis'.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0001">
                      <items id="text">structure</items>
                      <items id="description">@ internal @</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0002">
                      <items id="text">Problem/Diagnosis name</items>
                      <items id="description">Identification of the problem or diagnosis, by name.</items>
                      <items id="comment">Coding of the name of the problem or diagnosis with a terminology is preferred, where possible.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0003">
                      <items id="text">Date/time clinically recognised</items>
                      <items id="description">Estimated or actual date/time the diagnosis or problem was recognised by a healthcare professional.</items>
                      <items id="comment">Partial dates are acceptable. If the subject of care is under the age of one year, then the complete date or a minimum of the month and year is necessary to enable accurate age calculations - for example, if used to drive decision support. Data captured/imported as "Age at time of clinical recognition" should be converted to a date using the subject's date of birth.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0005">
                      <items id="text">Severity</items>
                      <items id="description">An assessment of the overall severity of the problem or diagnosis.</items>
                      <items id="comment">If severity is included in the Problem/diagnosis name via precoordinated codes, this data element becomes redundant. Note: more specific grading of severity can be recorded using the Specific details SLOT.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0009">
                      <items id="text">Clinical description</items>
                      <items id="description">Narrative description about the problem or diagnosis.</items>
                      <items id="comment">Use to provide background and context, including evolution, episodes or exacerbations, progress and any other relevant details, about the problem or diagnosis.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0012">
                      <items id="text">Body site</items>
                      <items id="description">Identification of a simple body site for the location of the problem or diagnosis.</items>
                      <items id="comment">Coding of the name of the anatomical location with a terminology is preferred, where possible.
Use this data element to record precoordinated anatomical locations. If the requirements for recording the anatomical location are determined at run-time by the application or require more complex modelling such as relative locations then use the CLUSTER.anatomical_location or CLUSTER.relative_location within the 'Structured anatomical location' SLOT in this archetype. Occurrences for this data element are unbounded to allow for clinical scenarios such as describing a rash in multiple locations but where all of the other attributes are identical. If the anatomical location is included in the Problem/diagnosis name via precoordinated codes, this data element becomes redundant.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0030">
                      <items id="text">Date/time of resolution</items>
                      <items id="description">Estimated or actual date/time of resolution or remission for this problem or diagnosis, as determined by a healthcare professional.</items>
                      <items id="comment">Partial dates are acceptable. If the subject of care is under the age of one year, then the complete date or a minimum of the month and year is necessary to enable accurate age calculations - for example, if used to drive decision support. Data captured/imported as "Age at time of resolution" should be converted to a date using the subject's date of birth.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0032">
                      <items id="text">Tree</items>
                      <items id="description">@ internal @</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0039">
                      <items id="text">Structured body site</items>
                      <items id="description">A structured anatomical location for the problem or diagnosis.</items>
                      <items id="comment">Use this SLOT to insert the CLUSTER.anatomical_location or CLUSTER.relative_location archetypes if the requirements for recording the anatomical location are determined at run-time by the application or require more complex modelling such as relative locations.

If the anatomical location is included in the Problem/diagnosis name via precoordinated codes, use of this SLOT becomes redundant.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0043">
                      <items id="text">Specific details</items>
                      <items id="description">Details that are additionally required to record as unique attributes of this problem or diagnosis.</items>
                      <items id="comment">May include structured detail about the grading or staging of the diagnosis; diagnostic criteria, classification criteria or formal severity assessments such as Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0046">
                      <items id="text">Status</items>
                      <items id="description">Structured details for location-, domain-, episode- or workflow-specific aspects of the diagnostic process.</items>
                      <items id="comment">Use status or context qualifiers with care, as they are variably used in practice and interoperability cannot be assured unless usage is clearly defined with the community of use. For example: active status - active, inactive, resolved, in remission; evolution status - initial, interim/working, final; temporal status - current, past; episodicity status - first, new, ongoing; admission status - admission, discharge; or priority status - primary, secondary.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0047">
                      <items id="text">Mild</items>
                      <items id="description">The problem or diagnosis does not interfere with normal activity or may cause damage to health if left untreated.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0048">
                      <items id="text">Moderate</items>
                      <items id="description">The problem or diagnosis causes interference with normal activity or will damage health if left untreated.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0049">
                      <items id="text">Severe</items>
                      <items id="description">The problem or diagnosis prevents normal activity or will seriously damage health if left untreated.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0069">
                      <items id="text">Comment</items>
                      <items id="description">Additional narrative about the problem or diagnosis not captured in other fields.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0070">
                      <items id="text">Last updated</items>
                      <items id="description">The date this problem or diagnosis was last updated.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0071">
                      <items id="text">Extension</items>
                      <items id="description">Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.</items>
                      <items id="comment">For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0072">
                      <items id="text">Course description</items>
                      <items id="description">Narrative description about the course of the problem or diagnosis since onset.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0073">
                      <items id="text">Diagnostic certainty</items>
                      <items id="description">The level of confidence in the identification of the diagnosis.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0074">
                      <items id="text">Suspected</items>
                      <items id="description">The diagnosis has been identified with a low level of certainty.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0075">
                      <items id="text">Probable</items>
                      <items id="description">The diagnosis has been identified with a high level of certainty.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0076">
                      <items id="text">Confirmed</items>
                      <items id="description">The diagnosis has been confirmed against recognised criteria.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                    <term_definitions code="at0077">
                      <items id="text">Date/time of onset</items>
                      <items id="description">Estimated or actual date/time that signs or symptoms of the problem/diagnosis were first observed.</items>
                      <items id="comment">Data captured/imported as "Age at onset" should be converted to a date using the subject's date of birth.</items>
                    </term_definitions>
                  </children>
                  <cardinality>
                    <is_ordered>false</is_ordered>
                    <is_unique>false</is_unique>

                      <lower_unbounded>false</lower_unbounded>
                      <upper_unbounded>true</upper_unbounded>
                      <lower>0</lower>
                    </interval>
                  </cardinality>
                </attributes>

                                <term_definitions code="at0000">
                                  <items id="text">Multimedia Resource</items>

                                <term_definitions code="at0001">
                                  <items id="text">Multimedia</items>

                                </term_definitions>

                </archetype_id>
                <term_definitions code="at0000">
                  <items id="text">CPR decision</items>
                  <items id="description">The advance recommendation as to whether cardio-pulmonary resuscitation should be undertaken or not. This is generally referred to in UK clinical guidance as the CPR (Cardio-pulmonary resuscitation) decision.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0001">
                  <items id="text">Tree</items>
                  <items id="description">@ internal @</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0002">
                  <items id="text">Date of CPR decision</items>
                  <items id="description">The date at which the CPR decision was originally taken or last reviewed.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0003">
                  <items id="text">CPR decision</items>
                  <items id="description">The advance recommendation as to whether cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) should be attempted. In some cases a clear answer may not be available to the recording clinician.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0004">
                  <items id="text">CPR attempts recommended adult or child</items>
                  <items id="description">Cardio-pulmonary resuscitation is recommended for adult or child.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0005">
                  <items id="text">CPR attempts not recommended adult or child.</items>
                  <items id="description">Cardiopulmonary resuscitation is not recommended for adult or child.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0006">
                  <items id="text">Patient awareness of decision</items>
                  <items id="description">Is the patient aware of the CPR decision?</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0007">
                  <items id="text">Patient not aware of CPR decision</items>
                  <items id="description">The patient is not aware of the cardiopulmonary resuscitation decision.</items>
                </term_definitions>

                        <term_definitions code="at0000">
                          <items id="text">Person name</items>
                          <items id="description">Details of personal name of an individual, provider or third party.</items>
                        </term_definitions>
                        <term_definitions code="at0001">
                          <items id="text">Unstructured name</items>
                          <items id="description">Name in free text unstructured format.</items>
                        </term_definitions>
                        <term_definitions code="at0002">
                          <items id="text">Structured name</items>
                          <items id="description">Name in structured format.</items>
                        </term_definitions>
                        <term_definitions code="at0003">
                          <items id="text">Given name</items>
                          <items id="description">Given / personal / first name.</items>
                        </term_definitions>
                        <term_definitions code="at0004">
                          <items id="text">Middle name</items>
                          <items id="description">Middle name or names.</items>
                        </term_definitions>
                        <term_definitions code="at0005">
                          <items id="text">Family name</items>
                          <items id="description">Family name or Surname.</items>
                        </term_definitions>
                        <term_definitions code="at0006">
                          <items id="text">Name type</items>
                          <items id="description">Type of name described.</items>
                        </term_definitions>
                        <term_definitions code="at0008">
                          <items id="text">Previous name</items>
                          <items id="description">Name previously used by this person.</items>
                        </term_definitions>
                        <term_definitions code="at0009">
                          <items id="text">Birth name</items>
                          <items id="description">Name given to this person at birth.</items>
                        </term_definitions>
                        <term_definitions code="at0010">
                          <items id="text">AKA</items>
                          <items id="description">Person also known as.</items>
                        </term_definitions>
                        <term_definitions code="at0011">
                          <items id="text">Alias</items>
                          <items id="description">Other name used by this person.</items>
                        </term_definitions>
                        <term_definitions code="at0012">
                          <items id="text">Maiden name</items>
                          <items id="description">Name used by this persion before marriage.</items>
                        </term_definitions>
                        <term_definitions code="at0014">
                          <items id="text">Validity period</items>
                          <items id="description">The date interval at which this name was valid.</items>
                        </term_definitions>
                        <term_definitions code="at0017">
                          <items id="text">Title</items>
                          <items id="description">The prefix or title used by the subject.</items>
                          <items id="comment">e.g. 'Mr', 'Mrs', 'Ms', 'Dr', 'Lord'</items>
                        </term_definitions>
                        <term_definitions code="at0018">
                          <items id="text">Suffix</items>
                          <items id="description">Additional term used following a person name.</items>
                          <items id="comment">e.g. 'Snr'</items>
                        </term_definitions>
                        <term_definitions code="at0019">
                          <items id="text">Professional name</items>
                          <items id="description">The name used by the subject for business or professional purposes.</items>
                        </term_definitions>
                        <term_definitions code="at0020">
                          <items id="text">Registered name</items>
                          <items id="description">The name by which the subject is officially registered.</items>
                        </term_definitions>
                        <term_definitions code="at0021">
                          <items id="text">Reporting name</items>
                          <items id="description">The subject’s name as it is to be used for reporting, when used with a specific identifier.</items>
                        </term_definitions>
                        <term_definitions code="at0022">
                          <items id="text">Preferred name</items>
                          <items id="description">Indicates that this is the name by which a person chooses to be identified.</items>
                        </term_definitions>
                      </children>

                  </children>

                <archetype_id>
                  <value>openEHR-EHR-ADMIN_ENTRY.capacity_respect.v0</value>
                </archetype_id>
                <term_definitions code="at0000">
                  <items id="text">Capacity ReSPECT</items>
                  <items id="description">Summary of capacity and representation information at the time of completing ReSPECT process.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0001">
                  <items id="text">Tree</items>
                  <items id="description">@ internal @</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0002">
                  <items id="text">Sufficient capacity</items>
                  <items id="description">Does the person have sufficient capacity to participate in making the recommendations on this plan?</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0003">
                  <items id="text">Legal proxy</items>
                  <items id="description">Do they have a legal proxy (e.g. welfare attorney, person with parental responsibility) who can participate on their behalf in making the recommendations?</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0004">
                  <items id="text">Yes</items>
                  <items id="description">The person has a legal proxy.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0005">
                  <items id="text">No</items>
                  <items id="description">The person does not have a legal proxy.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0006">
                  <items id="text">Unknown</items>
                  <items id="description">It is not known whether the person has a legal proxy.</items>
                </term_definitions>

                            </term_definitions>

                            <term_definitions code="at0017">

                              <items id="comment">e.g. 'Mr', 'Mrs', 'Ms', 'Dr', 'Lord'</items>

                            </term_definitions>

                            </term_definitions>
                            <term_definitions code="at0020">

                            <term_definitions code="at0021">

                            </term_definitions>

                <archetype_id>
                  <value>openEHR-EHR-ADMIN_ENTRY.involvement_respect.v0</value>
                </archetype_id>
                <term_definitions code="at0000">
                  <items id="text">Involvement ReSPECT</items>
                  <items id="description">Details of involvement in making plan.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0001">
                  <items id="text">Tree</items>
                  <items id="description">@ internal @</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0002">
                  <items id="text">Involvement</items>
                  <items id="description">Details of involvement in making this plan.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0003">
                  <items id="text">A Person has mental capacity</items>
                  <items id="description">This person has the mental capacity to participate in making these recommendations. They have been fully involved in making this plan.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0004">
                  <items id="text">B Person does not have mental capacity</items>
                  <items id="description">This person does not have the mental capacity to participate in making these recommendations. This plan has been made in accordance with capacity law, including, where applicable, in consultation with their legal proxy, or where no proxy, with relevant family members/friends.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0005">
                  <items id="text">C1 Person less than 18 or 16 with sufficient maturity</items>
                  <items id="description">This person is less than 18 (UK except Scotland) / 16 (Scotland) and they have sufficient maturity and understanding to participate in making this plan.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0007">
                  <items id="text">Reason for not selecting Options A or B or C</items>
                  <items id="description">Description of reason for not selecting Options A, B or C or where C1 or C2 is selected without selecting C3.</items>
                  <items id="comment">Additional implementation guidance: in an electronic format, if someone selects D we could have a line coming up explaining that the only legal reasons for selecting D are:
1. if the physician thinks it would cause the patient physiological or psychological harm
2. if the patient lacks capacity, and it is not practicable or appropriate to contact those close to them.
If C1 or C2 has been selected without selecting C3, please document why involvement of those holding parental responsibility has not been possible.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0009">
                  <items id="text">Location of record of discussion</items>
                  <items id="description">Details of location(s) of full documentation of conversations and decision-making process.</items>
                  <items id="comment">For example in GP Records dated xx/xx/xxxx.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0010">
                  <items id="text">C2 Person less than 18 or 16 without sufficient maturity</items>
                  <items id="description">This person is less than 18 (UK except Scotland) / 16 (Scotland) and they do not have sufficient maturity and understanding to participate in this plan. Their views, where known, have been taken into account.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0011">
                  <items id="text">C3 Person less than 18 or 16 parental decision</items>
                  <items id="description">This person is less than 18 (UK except Scotland) /16 (Scotland) and those holding parental responsibility have been fully involved in discussing and making this plan.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0012">
                  <items id="text">Involvement in recommendations</items>
                  <items id="description">The clinician(s) signing this plan is/are confirming that these recommendations have at least one of A, B or C or valid reason for not selecting A,B or C fully documented in clinical record.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0013">
                  <items id="text">D No other option selected</items>
                  <items id="description">No other option has been selected, and valid reason is stated below. Full explanation is documented in clinical record.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0014">
                  <items id="text">Date recommendations made</items>
                  <items id="description">Date when recommendations are made.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0015">
                  <items id="text">Name and role of those involved in decision making</items>
                  <items id="description">Name and role of those involved in decision making.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0016">
                  <items id="text">Link to record of discussion</items>
                  <items id="description">Link to record of discussion if held in a remote location.</items>
                </term_definitions>
              </children>

                </interval>
              </cardinality>

                <archetype_id>
                  <value>openEHR-EHR-ADMIN_ENTRY.relevant_contact_rcp.v0</value>
                </archetype_id>
                <term_definitions code="at0000">
                  <items id="text">Relevant contact</items>
                  <items id="description">Relevant contact for the patient or client, including formal and informal carers, next of kin, legal proxy and key workers.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0001">
                  <items id="text">Tree</items>
                  <items id="description">@ internal @</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0008">
                  <items id="text">Date updated</items>
                  <items id="description">The date at which the list of key contacts was created or updated.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0013">
                  <items id="text">Personal details</items>
                  <items id="description">Personal details of the relevant contact.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0017">
                  <items id="text">Note</items>
                  <items id="description">Any additional comment or note about the healthcare professional or carer or their role.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0025">
                  <items id="text">Is next of kin?</items>
                  <items id="description">True if this informal care is  the person's next-of-kin.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0030">
                  <items id="text">Relationship</items>
                  <items id="description">For an informal carer, the personal relationship with the client/carer e.g spouse or friend. For a formal carer, the professional role or responsibility of the carer with respect to the person which should help identify them as being an appropriate contact for an aspect of care, usually a professional role or care pathway name.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0035">
                  <items id="text">Relationship category</items>
                  <items id="description">The broad category of care relationship which the contact holds with the subject.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0036">
                  <items id="text">Informal carer</items>
                  <items id="description">An individual identified by the person as offering care and support, excluding paid carers or carers from voluntary agencies.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0037">
                  <items id="text">Main informal carer</items>
                  <items id="description">The contact is identified by the subject as being a primary informal source of care and support.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0038">
                  <items id="text">Formal care worker</items>
                  <items id="description">A health and social care professional or staff member, including a carer from voluntary sector.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0039">
                  <items id="text">Key formal care worker</items>
                  <items id="description">The formal carer is the subject's key worker.</items>
                </term_definitions>
              </children>

                        </term_definitions>

                        </term_definitions>

                          <items id="text">Name</items>

                        </term_definitions>

                <term_definitions code="at0000">
                  <items id="text">Relevant contact</items>
                  <items id="description">Relevant contact for the patient or client, including formal and informal carers, next of kin, legal proxy and key workers.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0001">
                  <items id="text">Tree</items>
                  <items id="description">@ internal @</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0008">
                  <items id="text">Date updated</items>
                  <items id="description">The date at which the list of key contacts was created or updated.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0013">
                  <items id="text">Personal details</items>
                  <items id="description">Personal details of the relevant contact.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0017">
                  <items id="text">Note</items>
                  <items id="description">Any additional comment or note about the healthcare professional or carer or their role.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0025">
                  <items id="text">Is next of kin?</items>
                  <items id="description">True if this informal care is  the person's next-of-kin.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0030">
                  <items id="text">Relationship</items>
                  <items id="description">For an informal carer, the personal relationship with the client/carer e.g spouse or friend. For a formal carer, the professional role or responsibility of the carer with respect to the person which should help identify them as being an appropriate contact for an aspect of care, usually a professional role or care pathway name.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0035">
                  <items id="text">Relationship category</items>
                  <items id="description">The broad category of care relationship which the contact holds with the subject.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0036">
                  <items id="text">Informal carer</items>
                  <items id="description">An individual identified by the person as offering care and support, excluding paid carers or carers from voluntary agencies.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0037">
                  <items id="text">Main informal carer</items>
                  <items id="description">The contact is identified by the subject as being a primary informal source of care and support.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0038">
                  <items id="text">Formal care worker</items>
                  <items id="description">A health and social care professional or staff member, including a carer from voluntary sector.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0039">
                  <items id="text">Key formal care worker</items>
                  <items id="description">The formal carer is the subject's key worker.</items>
                </term_definitions>
              </children>

                          <items id="description">Name in free text unstructured format.</items>
                        </term_definitions>

                          <items id="description">Name in structured format.</items>
                        </term_definitions>

                        </term_definitions>

                          <items id="description">Type of name described.</items>
                        </term_definitions>
                        <term_definitions code="at0008">

                          <items id="description">Name previously used by this person.</items>
                        </term_definitions>
                        <term_definitions code="at0009">

                          <items id="description">Name given to this person at birth.</items>

                        </term_definitions>
                        <term_definitions code="at0017">
                          <items id="text">Title</items>

                        </term_definitions>
                        <term_definitions code="at0018">
                          <items id="text">Suffix</items>

                          <items id="comment">e.g. 'Snr'</items>
                        </term_definitions>
                        <term_definitions code="at0019">
                          <items id="text">Professional name</items>
                          <items id="description">The name used by the subject for business or professional purposes.</items>
                        </term_definitions>
                        <term_definitions code="at0020">
                          <items id="text">Registered name</items>

                          <items id="description">Indicates that this is the name by which a person chooses to be identified.</items>

                        </term_definitions>

                        </term_definitions>

                          <items id="description">A structure for telephone numbers composed of separately identifiable elements. ENV13606-4:2000 7.11.18.</items>
                        </term_definitions>

                        </term_definitions>

                        </term_definitions>

                <term_definitions code="at0000">
                  <items id="text">Relevant contact</items>
                  <items id="description">Relevant contact for the patient or client, including formal and informal carers, next of kin, legal proxy and key workers.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0001">
                  <items id="text">Tree</items>
                  <items id="description">@ internal @</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0008">
                  <items id="text">Date updated</items>
                  <items id="description">The date at which the list of key contacts was created or updated.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0013">
                  <items id="text">Personal details</items>
                  <items id="description">Personal details of the relevant contact.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0017">
                  <items id="text">Note</items>
                  <items id="description">Any additional comment or note about the healthcare professional or carer or their role.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0025">
                  <items id="text">Is next of kin?</items>
                  <items id="description">True if this informal care is  the person's next-of-kin.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0030">
                  <items id="text">Relationship</items>
                  <items id="description">For an informal carer, the personal relationship with the client/carer e.g spouse or friend. For a formal carer, the professional role or responsibility of the carer with respect to the person which should help identify them as being an appropriate contact for an aspect of care, usually a professional role or care pathway name.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0035">
                  <items id="text">Relationship category</items>
                  <items id="description">The broad category of care relationship which the contact holds with the subject.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0036">
                  <items id="text">Informal carer</items>
                  <items id="description">An individual identified by the person as offering care and support, excluding paid carers or carers from voluntary agencies.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0037">
                  <items id="text">Main informal carer</items>
                  <items id="description">The contact is identified by the subject as being a primary informal source of care and support.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0038">
                  <items id="text">Formal care worker</items>
                  <items id="description">A health and social care professional or staff member, including a carer from voluntary sector.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0039">
                  <items id="text">Key formal care worker</items>
                  <items id="description">The formal carer is the subject's key worker.</items>
                </term_definitions>
              </children>

                <archetype_id>
                  <value>openEHR-EHR-ACTION.service.v0</value>
                </archetype_id>
                <term_definitions code="at0000">
                  <items id="text">Service</items>
                  <items id="description">A general clinical activity carried out for the patient to receive a specified service, advice or care from an expert healthcare provider.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0001">
                  <items id="text">Tree</items>
                  <items id="description">@ internal @</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0002">
                  <items id="text">Service planned</items>
                  <items id="description">Service request to healthcare provider is planned.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0003">
                  <items id="text">Service scheduled</items>
                  <items id="description">Appointment for a healthcare provider service has been made.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0004">
                  <items id="text">Service delivered</items>
                  <items id="description">The healthcare provider has delivered the service.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0005">
                  <items id="text">Service activity complete</items>
                  <items id="description">All service activities have been completed.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0006">
                  <items id="text">Service abandoned</items>
                  <items id="description">The referral has been ceased before the service has been completed.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0008">
                  <items id="text">Service postponed</items>
                  <items id="description">The planned service has been postponed.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0009">
                  <items id="text">Service cancelled</items>
                  <items id="description">The planned service has been cancelled prior to commencement.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0010">
                  <items id="text">Service suspended</items>
                  <items id="description">The service has been suspended without completion.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0011">
                  <items id="text">Service name</items>
                  <items id="description">Identification of the clinical service to be/being carried out.</items>
                  <items id="comment">Coding of the specific service name with a terminology is preferred, where possible.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0012">
                  <items id="text">Reason</items>
                  <items id="description">Reason that the activity or care pathway step for the identified service was carried out.</items>
                  <items id="comment">For example: the reason for the cancellation or suspension of the service.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0013">
                  <items id="text">Description</items>
                  <items id="description">Narrative description about the service, as appropriate for the pathway step.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0014">
                  <items id="text">Service type</items>
                  <items id="description">Type of service to be carried out or being carried out.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0015">
                  <items id="text">Tree</items>
                  <items id="description">@ internal @</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0016">
                  <items id="text">Requestor identifier</items>
                  <items id="description">The local ID assigned to the order by the healthcare provider or organisation requesting the service. This is also referred to as Placer Order Identifier.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0017">
                  <items id="text">Requestor</items>
                  <items id="description">Details about the healthcare provider or organisation requesting the service.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0018">
                  <items id="text">Receiver identifier</items>
                  <items id="description">The ID assigned to the order by the healthcare provider or organisation receiving the request for referral. This is also referred to as Filler Order Identifier.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0019">
                  <items id="text">Receiver</items>
                  <items id="description">Details about the healthcare provider or organisation receiving the request for referral.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0021">
                  <items id="text">Sequence</items>
                  <items id="description">The sequence of the specified clinical service.</items>
                  <items id="comment">Only for use in association with the 'Service delivered' pathway step. For example: record that this is the 3rd physiotherapy appointment in a planned sequence.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0023">
                  <items id="text">Service expired</items>
                  <items id="description">The referral has expired before the referral episode has been completed.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0025">
                  <items id="text">Scheduled date/time</items>
                  <items id="description">The date and/or time on which the service is intended to be performed.</items>
                  <items id="comment">Only for use in association with the 'Service scheduled' pathway step.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0026">
                  <items id="text">Service request sent</items>
                  <items id="description">Request for service sent.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0027">
                  <items id="text">Service detail</items>
                  <items id="description">Structured information about the service.</items>
                  <items id="comment">Use to capture detailed, structured information about specified aspects of the service.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0028">
                  <items id="text">Comment</items>
                  <items id="description">Additional narrative about the activity or care pathway step not captured in other fields.</items>
                </term_definitions>
                <term_definitions code="at0029">
                  <items id="text">Multimedia</items>
                  <items id="description">Mulitimedia representation of a performed service.</items>
                </term_definitions>
              </children>
              <cardinality>
                <is_ordered>false</is_ordered>
                <is_unique>false</is_unique>
                <interval>
                  <lower_included>true</lower_included>
                  <lower_unbounded>false</lower_unbounded>
                  <upper_unbounded>true</upper_unbounded>
                  <lower>0</lower>
                </interval>
              </cardinality>
            </attributes>
          </children>
          <cardinality>

            <is_unique>false</is_unique>
            <interval>

              <lower_unbounded>false</lower_unbounded>
              <upper_unbounded>true</upper_unbounded>
              <lower>1</lower>
            </interval>
          </cardinality>
        </attributes>
        <archetype_id>
          <value>openEHR-EHR-SECTION.respect_headings.v0</value>
        </archetype_id>
        <term_definitions code="at0000">
          <items id="text">ReSPECT headings</items>
          <items id="description">Top level heading for capturing details of ReSPECT process.</items>
        </term_definitions>
        <term_definitions code="at0001">
          <items id="text">2. Summary of relevant information</items>
          <items id="description">Heading containing summary of relevant information for the ReSPECT process.</items>
        </term_definitions>
        <term_definitions code="at0002">
          <items id="text">2.1 Key diagnoses</items>
          <items id="description">Details of the key diagnoses leading to the need for a ReSPECT form.</items>
        </term_definitions>
        <term_definitions code="at0003">
          <items id="text">2.2 Other relevant conditions</items>
          <items id="description">Details of other significant conditions relevant to the ReSPECT form.</items>
        </term_definitions>
        <term_definitions code="at0005">
          <items id="text">2.3 Other relevant planning documents</items>
          <items id="description">Details of other relevant planning documents and where to find them (e.g. Advance Decision to Refuse Treatment, Advance Care Plan). Also include known wishes about organ donation.</items>
        </term_definitions>
        <term_definitions code="at0006">
          <items id="text">3. Personal preferences</items>
          <items id="description">Details of personal preferences to guide this ReSPECT plan (where the person has capacity).</items>
        </term_definitions>
        <term_definitions code="at0007">
          <items id="text">4. Clinical recommendations</items>
          <items id="description">Summary of clinical recommendations for emergency care and treatment.</items>
        </term_definitions>
        <term_definitions code="at0008">
          <items id="text">5. Capacity and representation</items>
          <items id="description">Details of capacity and representation at the time of completion of the ReSPECT form.</items>
        </term_definitions>
        <term_definitions code="at0009">
          <items id="text">6. Involvement in making plan</items>
          <items id="description">Details of those involved and discussions in making the ReSPECT plan.</items>
        </term_definitions>
        <term_definitions code="at0010">
          <items id="text">7. Clinician signatures</items>
          <items id="description">Details of clinicians involved in making ReSPECT plan.</items>
          <items id="comment">Implementation guidance - Add prompt to UI: The clinical signature is to indicate that the decision-making process has fully complied with relevant capacity and Human Rights legislation.</items>
        </term_definitions>
        <term_definitions code="at0011">
          <items id="text">8. Emergency contacts</items>
          <items id="description">Details of emergency contacts for ReSPECT plan.</items>
        </term_definitions>
        <term_definitions code="at0012">
          <items id="text">9. Confirmation of validity</items>
          <items id="description">Details of review dates and clinician for the confirmation of validity (e.g. for change of condition).</items>
        </term_definitions>
        <term_definitions code="at0013">
          <items id="text">2.0 Relevant information</items>
          <items id="description">Narrative and structured details of relevant information.</items>
        </term_definitions>
      </children>
      <cardinality>
        <is_ordered>false</is_ordered>
        <is_unique>false</is_unique>
        <interval>
          <lower_included>true</lower_included>
          <lower_unbounded>false</lower_unbounded>
          <upper_unbounded>true</upper_unbounded>
          <lower>0</lower>
        </interval>
      </cardinality>
    </attributes>
    <archetype_id>
      <value>openEHR-EHR-COMPOSITION.report.v1</value>
    </archetype_id>

    </template_id>
    <term_definitions code="at0000">
      <items id="text">Report</items>
      <items id="description">Document to communicate information to others, commonly in response to a request from another party.</items>
    </term_definitions>
    <term_definitions code="at0001">
      <items id="text">Tree</items>
      <items id="description">@ internal @</items>
    </term_definitions>
    <term_definitions code="at0002">
      <items id="text">Report ID</items>
      <items id="description">Identification information about the report.</items>
    </term_definitions>
    <term_definitions code="at0005">
      <items id="text">Status</items>
      <items id="description">The status of the entire report. Note: This is not the status of any of the report components.</items>
    </term_definitions>
    <term_definitions code="at0006">
      <items id="text">Extension</items>
      <items id="description">Additional information required to capture local context or to align with other reference models/formalisms.</items>
      <items id="comment">For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.</items>
    </term_definitions>
  </definition>
